adjective.description: Having an even and regular surface or consistency; free from perceptible projections, lumps, or indentations.
examples: a smooth skin tans more easily
the trucks gave a smooth ride
graphics are excellent, with fast, smooth scrolling

adjective.description: (of an action, event, or process) without problems or difficulties.
examples: the group's expansion into the U.S. market was not quite so smooth

adjective.description: (of a person or their manner, actions, or words) suavely charming in a way considered to be unctuous.
(of food or drink) without harshness or bitterness.
examples: a lovely, smooth, very fruity wine

verb.description: Give (something) a flat, regular surface or appearance by running one's hand over it.

adverb.description: In a way that is without difficulties.
examples: the course of true love never did run smooth

origin: Old English smōth, probably of Germanic origin, though no cognates are known. The verb dates from Middle English.
